Every table I've ever played on has a slightly smaller cue ball. The table didn't use a magnet to determine the ball. All it was, was a gap smaller than every other ball, except the cue ball. The cue ball would fall down onto it's own return shoot.

It's a stupid design that only allows you to get back the cue ball. I always thought it was ridiculous. You can only play 8-Ball on it. Yawn! I was hoping for notions of a central magnet to act as a pseudo-gravity well for making the game more interesting. If you had an array of electro-magnets you could change the strength and position of a number of pseudo-gravity wells from game to game to keep the challenge from becoming routine. If the invisibility was too much of a problem you could have the surface be transparent over a layer of ferro-magnetic fluids which would show the strength and location of the various fields. Maybe the challenge wouldn't even be to sink the standard set of pools balls in the standard pockets, but to try to sink a single goal on the opposite side of the table more times than your opponent.
